answer_html: The coefficient of x3 term is -1/2 and so the correct answer is D.
answer_latex:
The coefficient of \emph{x}\textsuperscript{3} term is -1/2 and so the
correct answer is D.
hints_html: The Taylor series of \(\displaystyle x \ln(1-x)\) is the Taylor series of \(\displaystyle \ln(1-x)\) multiplied by x.
hints_latex:
The Taylor series of $\displaystyle x \ln(1-x)$ is the Taylor series of
$\displaystyle \ln(1-x)$ multiplied by \emph{x}.
hints_raw: The Taylor series of <math>\displaystyle x \ln(1-x)</math> is the Taylor series of <math>\displaystyle \ln(1-x)</math> multiplied by ''x''.
question: 1 (f)
sols_html:
Recall that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \ln(1-x) = -x -\frac{x^2}2 -\frac{x^3}3 - \cdots,\end{aligned}\]

therefore

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle x \ln(1-x)= -x^2 - \frac{x^3}2 - \frac{x^4} 3-\cdots\end{aligned}\]

The coefficient of x3 term is -1/2 and so the correct answer is D.

If you don’t remember the Taylor series about x = 0 of \(\displaystyle \ln(1-x)\) you can simply re-compute it. Recall that the Taylor series of a function \(f\) about the point x = a is

\[\begin{aligned} f(a) + f'(a)(x-a) + \frac{f''(a)}{2!}(x-a)^2 + \frac{f^{(3)}(a)}{3!}(x-a)^3 + \ldots\end{aligned}\]

For the function

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f(x) = \ln(1-x)\end{aligned}\]

we have

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f'(a) = -\frac{1}{1-a} \quad f''(a) = -\frac{1}{(1-a)^2} \quad f^{(3)}(a) = -\frac{2}{(1-a)^3}\end{aligned}\]

and so at a = 0 we obtain

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f'(0) = -1 \quad f''(0) = -1 \quad f^{(3)}(x) = -2\end{aligned}\]

And so the Taylor series of \(\displaystyle \ln(1-x)\) around x = 0 is

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle - x - \frac{1}{2} x^2 - \frac{1}{3}x^3 + \ldots\end{aligned}\]

And hence the Taylor series of \(\displaystyle x \ln(1-x)\) around x = 0 is

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle - x^2 - \frac{1}{2} x^3 - \frac{1}{3} x^4 + \ldots\end{aligned}\]

And we can observe that the x3 coefficient is -1/2 which is the answer D.
sols_raw:
Recall that

:<math>
\displaystyle \ln(1-x) = -x -\frac{x^2}2 -\frac{x^3}3 - \cdots,
</math>

therefore

:<math>
\displaystyle x \ln(1-x)= -x^2 - \frac{x^3}2 - \frac{x^4} 3-\cdots
</math>

The coefficient of ''x''<sup>3</sup> term is -1/2 and so the correct answer is D.
If you don't remember the Taylor series about ''x'' = 0 of <math>\displaystyle \ln(1-x)</math> you can simply re-compute it. Recall that the Taylor series of a function &fnof; about the point ''x'' = ''a'' is
:<math>
f(a) + f'(a)(x-a) + \frac{f''(a)}{2!}(x-a)^2 + \frac{f^{(3)}(a)}{3!}(x-a)^3 + \ldots
</math>

For the function
:<math>\displaystyle
f(x) = \ln(1-x)
</math>
we have
:<math>\displaystyle
f'(a) = -\frac{1}{1-a} \quad f''(a) = -\frac{1}{(1-a)^2} \quad f^{(3)}(a) = -\frac{2}{(1-a)^3}
</math>
and so at ''a'' = 0 we obtain
:<math>\displaystyle
f'(0) = -1 \quad f''(0) = -1 \quad f^{(3)}(x) = -2
</math>

And so the Taylor series of <math>\displaystyle \ln(1-x)</math> around ''x'' = 0 is
:<math>\displaystyle
- x - \frac{1}{2} x^2 - \frac{1}{3}x^3 + \ldots
</math>

And hence the Taylor series of <math>\displaystyle x \ln(1-x)</math> around ''x'' = 0 is
:<math>\displaystyle
- x^2 - \frac{1}{2} x^3 - \frac{1}{3} x^4 + \ldots
</math>

And we can observe that the ''x''<sup>3</sup> coefficient is -1/2 which is the answer D.
statement_html:
Answer the following multiple choice question. Check your answer very carefully. Your answer will be marked right or wrong (work will not be considered for this problem).

In the Taylor series of \(\displaystyle x \ln(1-x)\) (about the point x = 0), the coefficient of the x3 term is

A. 1/3

B. -1/3

C. 1/2

D. -1/2
statement_raw:
Answer the following multiple choice question. Check your answer very carefully. Your answer will be marked right or wrong (work will not be considered for this problem).

In the Taylor series of <math> \displaystyle x \ln(1-x)</math> (about the point ''x'' = 0), the coefficient of the ''x''<sup>3</sup> term is

:A. 1/3

:B. -1/3

:C. 1/2

:D. -1/2
